messageHeadline: fix: Fix syntax highlighting disappearing on hover by passing filenam‚Ä¶
message:
fix: Fix syntax highlighting disappearing on hover by passing filename prop (#74)

* fix: Fix syntax highlighting disappearing on hover by passing filename prop

Pass filename as a prop through the component hierarchy instead of relying on the global currentFilename variable. This ensures each diff line uses the correct filename for language detection.

* refactor: Remove global currentFilename variable

Remove the global currentFilename variable and setCurrentFilename function as they are no longer needed. All components now receive filename through props.

pullRequests.title: fix: Fix syntax highlighting disappearing on hover by passing filename prop
pullRequests.body:
## Summary
- Fix syntax highlighting that disappears when hovering over files, especially with large diffs
- Pass filename as a prop through the component hierarchy instead of relying on the global currentFilename variable
- Remove the global currentFilename variable completely as it was causing issues

## Problem
When hovering over diff lines, all lines were using the same global `currentFilename` variable for language detection, causing incorrect syntax highlighting. The global variable approach was fundamentally flawed as it couldn't handle multiple files being rendered simultaneously.

## Solution
- Added `filename` prop to `PrismSyntaxHighlighter`, `EnhancedPrismSyntaxHighlighter`, `DiffLineRow`, `DiffChunk`, and `SideBySideDiffChunk`
- Pass the actual filename from `DiffViewer` through the component hierarchy
- Each component now receives the correct filename for proper language detection
- Removed the global `currentFilename` variable and `setCurrentFilename` function entirely

## Why global variables were problematic
Using a global variable for filename was a mistake because:
- Multiple files can be rendered at the same time in the diff view
- React components can re-render in any order
- The global state could be overwritten by any component, causing all components to use the wrong filename

## Test plan
- [x] Tested locally with large diffs
- [x] Verified syntax highlighting remains stable when hovering
- [x] All tests pass

* feat: Add performance comparison script

Create a script to compare two performance measurement results and display
the differences in a clear, readable format. Supports both Markdown and JSON
output formats.

Features:
- Compare average operation times and identify improvements/regressions
- Support for automatic detection of latest results by size
- Markdown table output with color-coded changes
- JSON output for programmatic processing
- Ability to save comparison results to file

Usage:
- pnpm compare:perf - Compare latest two medium results
- pnpm compare:perf small - Compare latest two small results
- pnpm compare:perf file1.json file2.json - Compare specific files
- pnpm compare:perf small --json - Output as JSON
- pnpm compare:perf small --save - Save markdown to file

* perf: Improve performance measurement timing accuracy

- Use setTimeout(0) before requestAnimationFrame to allow React's concurrent features to complete
- This provides more accurate measurement of actual navigation performance
- Add experimental test scripts to .gitignore

* perf: Optimize PrismSyntaxHighlighter to prevent re-renders

Add React.memo to both PrismSyntaxHighlighter and EnhancedPrismSyntaxHighlighter
components to prevent unnecessary re-renders during keyboard navigation.

Performance improvement:
- Baseline: 474.05ms average navigation time
- Optimized: 86.67ms average navigation time
- Result: 81.7% reduction in keyboard navigation latency

The optimization is particularly effective for large diffs with many syntax
highlighted code blocks, as it prevents re-rendering of unchanged code when
parent components update during navigation.

Also added useCallback for render functions to ensure proper memoization.

* feat: Add GitHub Actions workflow for performance testing

- Run performance tests on PRs comparing base vs head branches
- Show results in Job Summary and PR comments
- Fail the workflow if performance degrades by more than 10%
- Mark as improved if performance increases by more than 5%
- Handle cases where performance scripts don't exist in base branch

* feat: Add playwright as dev dependency and improve CI workflow

- Add playwright as a dev dependency in package.json
- Update GitHub Actions workflow to use the compare script properly
- Use JSON output from compare script for accurate data extraction
- Properly handle both compare and compare-fallback outputs in Job Summary

* refactor: Improve CI workflow to use head branch scripts consistently

- Setup Node.js and pnpm first before any checkouts
- Use head branch's measurement scripts to test both head and base builds
- This ensures consistent measurement methodology across versions
- Better handling of cases where base branch might have incompatible changes
- Add number formatting for cleaner display in Job Summary and PR comments

* fix: Install playwright in base branch if missing during CI

- Check if playwright is installed before running performance tests
- Install it temporarily with --no-save if missing
- This ensures tests can run even when base branch doesn't have playwright as a dependency

* fix: Use pnpm to install playwright in CI to handle workspace protocols

- Switch from npm to pnpm for installing playwright in base branch
- Fallback to npm if pnpm fails (for older versions)
- This fixes the 'Unsupported URL Type "link:"' error when base branch uses pnpm workspaces

* fix: Use pnpm exec instead of npx and remove npm fallback

- Use 'pnpm exec' instead of 'npx' for consistency
- Remove unnecessary npm fallback since we're already using pnpm
- Simplify the playwright installation logic

* ci: Remove PR comment functionality from performance workflow

Removed PR comment functionality from the GitHub Actions performance

pullRequests.title: perf: Improve keyboard navigation performance with React.memo
pullRequests.body:
## Summary

This PR optimizes the performance of keyboard navigation in large diffs by preventing unnecessary re-renders of syntax highlighter components.

## Changes

### Performance Optimizations
- Added React.memo to `PrismSyntaxHighlighter` and `EnhancedPrismSyntaxHighlighter` components
- Used useCallback for render functions to ensure proper memoization
- Result: **81.7% reduction** in keyboard navigation latency (474ms ‚Üí 87ms)

### Performance Measurement Infrastructure
- Created performance measurement scripts for consistent testing
- Added comparison tool to track performance changes between commits
- Improved measurement timing accuracy to properly capture React rendering

### CI/CD Improvements
- Added GitHub Actions workflow for automated performance testing on PRs
- Tests compare base vs head branch performance
- Fails PR if performance degrades by >10%
- Shows results in Job Summary and PR comments

## Performance Results

| Metric | Before | After | Improvement |
|--------|--------|-------|-------------|
| Average Navigation Time | 474.05ms | 86.67ms | 81.7% faster |

The optimization is particularly effective for large diffs with many syntax highlighted code blocks.

## Test Plan
- [x] Run performance tests locally with `pnpm perf`
- [x] Compare results with `pnpm perf:compare`
- [x] Verify no visual or functional changes
- [x] Test GitHub Actions workflow on this PR

messageHeadline: fix: Fix issue where last comment is not output when closing window (‚Ä¶
message:
fix: Fix issue where last comment is not output when closing window (#63)

## Problem
- When posting multiple comments, the last comment was not displayed in stdout
- Each time a comment was added, the old state was being sent due to useEffect cleanup

## Root Cause
- The useEffect dependency array included `comments`, causing:
  1. Previous effect cleanup to execute on each comment update
  2. Old comments state (without the new comment) to be sent
  3. New effect to be set up

## Solution
1. Client-side:
   - Use `commentsRef` to maintain reference to latest comments
   - Set up `beforeunload` event listener only once (empty dependency array)
   - Prevents unnecessary sends when adding comments

2. Server-side:
   - Add 100ms delay when SSE connection closes
   - Ensures `sendBeacon` requests are properly processed

## Related Info
- This bug was introduced in commit 606f5282 (2025-07-01)
- Implemented in PR #9 "Add comment export feature on process termination"

ü§ñ Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.ai/code)

Co-authored-by: Claude <noreply@anthropic.com>

pullRequests.title: feat: Add stdin support for reading unified diffs
pullRequests.body:
## Summary

This PR adds support for reading unified diffs from stdin, enabling powerful pipeline workflows with difit.

## Features

- **Automatic detection**: Detects piped input via `\!process.stdin.isTTY`
- **Explicit mode**: Use `-` argument to force reading from stdin
- **Full compatibility**: Reuses existing diff parsing logic for consistency
- **Flexible workflows**: Works with any tool that outputs unified diff format

## Usage Examples

```bash
# Basic usage - pipe git diff output
git diff | npx difit

# Explicit stdin mode
git diff | npx difit -

# Custom context lines
git diff -U10 | npx difit

# Compare against merge base
git diff --merge-base main feature | npx difit

# View diffs from other tools
diff -u file1.txt file2.txt | npx difit

# Review saved patches
cat changes.patch | npx difit
```

## Implementation Details

- Added `readStdin()` function to read from process.stdin
- Created `parseStdinDiff()` method that leverages existing `parseUnifiedDiff()`
- Extracted `countLinesFromChunks()` helper to avoid code duplication
- Added comprehensive test coverage in `git-diff.test.ts`
- Updated server to handle pre-parsed diff data from stdin

## Test Plan

- [x] Added 9 new test cases for stdin parsing functionality
- [x] Added unit test for `countLinesFromChunks` helper
- [x] All existing tests pass (209 passed)
- [x] Manual testing with various diff sources
- [x] ESLint and TypeScript checks pass

## Notes

- Syntax highlighting works as expected (language detection from filenames in diff)
- Comments work but use a generic storage key since there's no git commit hash
- Image diffs cannot be displayed (no access to actual file content)

pullRequests.title: fix: handle empty files in keyboard navigation
pullRequests.body:
## Summary
- Fixed keyboard navigation to properly handle empty files and chunks
- Prevents navigation from getting stuck when encountering files with no content
- Added comprehensive test coverage for empty file scenarios

## Problem
Keyboard navigation would break in rare cases when encountering:
- Empty files (files with no chunks)
- Files with empty chunks (chunks with no lines)

This can occur in edge cases such as:
- Files temporarily added with `git add -N` (intent to add) that are later deleted
- Certain diff scenarios where files exist but have no actual content changes
- Other rare cases where the diff parser produces empty chunks/lines

## Solution
Modified the `advancePosition` function in `navigationCore.ts` to:
- Continue advancing through empty files/chunks instead of returning invalid positions
- Properly wrap around when all files are empty (to prevent infinite loops)
- Skip to the next file with actual content when normal advancement fails

## Test plan
- [x] Added comprehensive tests for empty file scenarios
- [x] All existing tests pass
- [x] Linting passes
- [x] Manually tested keyboard navigation with empty files

pullRequests.title: Add Hot Reload Feature with File Watching and Manual Refresh
pullRequests.body:
## Summary

Added a hot reload feature that automatically detects repository changes and provides a GitHub-style manual reload button. This implementation uses high-performance file watching with mode-aware monitoring strategies.

### difit --watch

https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/6a761f19-b1ba-4ee7-baa8-55d3fa3eb9b5

### difit . --watch

https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/70d1351d-e2e4-4baf-80a4-ada9345b0fb8

## Key Features

- **Automatic Change Detection**: Monitors file changes and commits based on diff mode
- **GitHub-style Reload Button**: Orange-colored reload button that appears when changes are detected
- **Smart Mode-aware Watching**: Different monitoring strategies for each diff mode (DEFAULT, WORKING, STAGED, DOT)
- **Gitignore Support**: Respects .gitignore patterns when watching working directory
- **Real-time Communication**: Server-Sent Events (SSE) for instant change notifications
- **Comprehensive Testing**: 265 test cases covering all components and edge cases

## Usage

Enable file watching by adding the `--watch` flag to any difit command:

```bash
# Watch for new commits when viewing HEAD diff
difit --watch

# Watch for file changes when viewing working directory
difit . --watch

# Watch for staging changes
difit working --watch

# Watch for uncommitted changes (files + commits)
difit HEAD main --watch
```

When changes are detected, an orange "Reload" button appears next to the "Ignore Whitespace" toggle. Click it to refresh the diff view with the latest changes.

**Note**: The `--watch` flag is currently supported only in GUI mode. TUI support will be added in future releases.

## Design Decisions

- **Manual Reload vs Auto-reload**: Chose manual reload button over automatic refresh to prevent disrupting the review experience when AI tools are running in the background
- **GUI-first Implementation**: Started with GUI support as it provides better user experience for the reload button. TUI support is planned for future releases

## Implementation Details

### Architecture Overview

```
‚îå‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îê    SSE     ‚îå‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îê    File Events    ‚îå‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îê
‚îÇ   React Client  ‚îÇ ‚óÑ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚ñ∫ ‚îÇ   Express Server ‚îÇ ‚óÑ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚ñ∫ ‚îÇ @parcel/watcher ‚îÇ
‚îÇ                 ‚îÇ            ‚îÇ                  ‚îÇ                   ‚îÇ                 ‚îÇ
‚îÇ - ReloadButton  ‚îÇ            ‚îÇ - FileWatcher    ‚îÇ                   ‚îÇ - .git/HEAD     ‚îÇ
‚îÇ - useFileWatch  ‚îÇ            ‚îÇ - SSE Endpoint   ‚îÇ                   ‚îÇ - .git/index    ‚îÇ
‚îÇ - App.tsx       ‚îÇ            ‚îÇ - Cache Manager  ‚îÇ                   ‚îÇ - Working files ‚îÇ
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îò            ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îò                   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îò
```

### File Watching Strategy by Mode

- **DEFAULT Mode**: Watches `.git/HEAD` for new commits
- **WORKING Mode**: Watches working directory + staging area for file changes
- **STAGED Mode**: Watches `.git/index` for staging changes  
- **DOT Mode**: Watches working directory + commits for uncommitted changes
- **SPECIFIC Mode**: No watching (static commit comparison)

### Core Components

- **FileWatcherService**: High-performance file monitoring with @parcel/watcher
- **ReloadButton**: GitHub-style UI component with loading states
- **useFileWatch**: React hook for SSE communication and state management
- **Type System**: Comprehensive TypeScript definitions for watch events

## Changes Made

### New Files
- `src/types/watch.ts` - Shared type definitions for watch functionality
- `src/server/file-watcher.ts` - Core file watching service implementation
- `src/client/hooks/useFileWatch.ts` - React hook for file watch integration
- `src/client/components/ReloadButton.tsx` - GitHub-style reload button component

### Enhanced Files
- `src/server/server.ts` - Added SSE endpoint and cache invalidation
- `src/client/App.tsx` - Integrated reload button with keyboard navigation
- `src/cli/index.ts` - Added --watch flag and diff mode detection

### Test Coverage
- **29 ReloadButton tests**: Visibility, states, interactions, accessibility
- **13 useFileWatch tests**: SSE connection, reconnection, error handling
- **14 FileWatcherService tests**: Mode-specific watching, gitignore, debouncing
- **Additional CLI tests**: Watch functionality and mode detection

## Technical Highlights

- **Debounced Change Detection** (300ms): Prevents excessive reload notifications
- **Gitignore Integration**: Uses simple-git's checkIgnore for accurate file filtering
- **Auto-reconnection**: SSE connections automatically recover from network issues
- **Orange Color Scheme**: Matches GitHub's design language for reload buttons
- **Memory Efficient**: Proper cleanup of watchers and event listeners

ü§ñ Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.ai/code)

Co-Authored-By: Claude <noreply@anthropic.com>

pullRequests.title: feat: Add support for @ symbol as Git HEAD alias
pullRequests.body:
## Summary
- Add support for `@` symbol as a Git HEAD alias in difit
- Allow `@` with parent/ancestor references like `@^`, `@~3`, etc.
- Fix validation that was explicitly rejecting `@` despite it being a valid Git reference

## Changes
- Updated `validateCommitish` function to recognize `@` patterns with regex `/^@(~\d+|\^\d*)*$/`
- Removed explicit rejection of `@` from `isValidBranchName` function
- Added comprehensive tests for `@` symbol usage
- Updated README with `@` usage examples

## Test plan
- [x] Added new test cases for `@`, `@^`, `@~1`, `@~2^1` etc.
- [x] All existing tests pass
- [x] Manually verified `git log -1 @` and `git log -1 @~3` work correctly
- [x] Build and lint checks pass

## Why this matters
Git has supported `@` as an alias for HEAD since version 1.8.5. This is a common shorthand that many Git users expect to work. The previous validation was unnecessarily restrictive.

Example usage:
```bash
npx difit @          # Same as npx difit HEAD
npx difit @ main     # Compare HEAD with main
npx difit @^ @~3     # Compare previous commit with 3 commits ago
```

pullRequests.title: feat: Add Gerrit-style keyboard navigation
pullRequests.body: ## Summary This PR introduces comprehensive Gerrit-style keyboard navigation to difit, enabling users to efficiently navigate through diffs using keyboard shortcuts. The implementation includes visual cursor highlighting, smart scrolling, and a help modal. ## Key Features ### üéØ Navigation Commands - **Line Navigation**: `j`/`k` or `‚Üì`/`‚Üë` - Navigate between diff lines - **File Navigation**: `]`/`[` - Jump between files - **Chunk Navigation**: `n`/`p` - Navigate between change chunks (added/deleted lines) - **Comment Navigation**: `N`/`P` (Shift+n/p) - Jump between comments - **Side Navigation**: `h`/`l` or `‚Üê`/`‚Üí` - Switch between left/right sides (side-by-side mode only) ### üîß Actions - **Review Toggle**: `r` - Mark file as reviewed/unreviewed (with auto-scroll to file header) - **Add Comment**: `c` - Create comment at current line (not on deleted lines) - **Copy Comments**: `Shift+C` - Copy all comments prompt to clipboard - **Center View**: `.` - Move cursor to center of viewport - **Help**: `?` - Toggle keyboard shortcuts help modal ### üé® Visual Improvements - Visual cursor highlighting with blue outline (#4d7adb) - Responsive 2-column help modal layout on larger screens (‚â•1024px) - Smart scrolling that positions focused elements at 1/3 from top - Skip collapsed/reviewed files during navigation ### üî® Technical Improvements - Modular architecture with separate files for navigation logic - Comprehensive test coverage (1000+ lines of tests) - Filter-based navigation system for extensibility - Proper handling of side-by-side vs inline modes - Mouse click integration to set cursor position ## Implementation Details The keyboard navigation is implemented using: - A custom React hook (`useKeyboardNavigation`) that manages cursor state - Filter-based navigation system that makes it easy to define navigation targets - Smart scrolling behavior inspired by Gerrit's implementation - Proper handling of edge cases (deleted lines, paired add/delete lines, etc.) ## Test plan - [x] All existing tests pass - [x] Added comprehensive test suite for keyboard navigation (24 test cases) - [x] Pre-commit hooks pass (format, typecheck, test, lint) - [x] Manual testing of all keyboard shortcuts - [x] Manual testing in both side-by-side and inline modes - [x] Manual testing of help modal responsiveness - [ ] Manual testing with large diffs ü§ñ Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.ai/code)

messageHeadline: feat: add --clean flag to clear existing comments on startup (#51)
message:
feat: add --clean flag to clear existing comments on startup (#51)

Add a command-line flag that allows users to start with a clean slate by clearing
all existing comments when launching difit. This is useful when starting a new
review session and wanting to remove previous review comments.

- Add --clean CLI flag

pullRequests.title: feat: Add ability to delete all existing comments
pullRequests.body:
Thank you for creating difit\! It's an incredibly useful tool for code reviews. This PR adds functionality to help manage comments across multiple review sessions.

### Problem

When using difit for multiple review sessions:
1. Comments from previous sessions remain visible even after code changes
2. Comments on lines that no longer exist in the diff cannot be deleted through the UI
3. There's no way to start a fresh review session without old comments

### Solution

This PR introduces two ways to delete all existing comments:

#### 1. UI Button - "Delete All Comments"
- Added a red button next to "Copy All Comments" button
- Shows confirmation dialog before deletion
- Allows users to clear all comments during a review session

#### 2. CLI Flag - `--clean`
- Start difit with a clean slate by clearing all existing comments on startup
- Usage: `difit --clean`
- Only clears comments once on initial load (new comments added during the session are not affected)

### Implementation Details

- Modified `useLocalComments` hook to expose the existing `clearAllComments` function
- Added confirmation dialog using `window.confirm()` for safety
- Used `useRef` to ensure CLI flag only triggers cleanup once
- Added comprehensive tests for both UI and CLI functionality

### Testing

- Added tests for `useLocalComments` hook
- Added tests for App component (UI button functionality)
- Added tests for CLI flag functionality
- All existing tests pass

### Breaking Changes

None. This is a purely additive feature.

  - Add a handleKeyDown function: Allows the checkbox to be toggled with Enter and Space keys
  - onKeyDown={handleKeyDown}: Adds a keyboard event listener

pullRequests.title: Add multi-line comment support for diff viewer
pullRequests.body:
## Overview
This PR introduces multi-line comment functionality to the diff viewer, allowing users to select and comment on multiple lines of code at once.

| Side by Side | Inline |
|--------|--------|
| ![CleanShot 0007-07-10 at 08 30 02](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/4783751a-a52d-4f72-bb94-31ec9c412782) | ![CleanShot 0007-07-10 at 08 30 28](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/525dffce-3875-4371-a198-a5f5e76c5a93) |

## Changes
- Enhanced the diff viewer components to support multi-line selection
- Updated comment handling logic to work with line ranges instead of single lines
- Modified the SideBySideDiffChunk component to handle multi-line comment interactions
- Updated the comment data structure to support line ranges
- Added visual styling for multi-line selections
- **Breaking Change**: Updated comment position format from `<path>:<line>` to `<path>:L<line>` for single lines and `<path>:L<line>-L<line>` for multi-line ranges (following GitHub's line reference format)
  - e.g. https://github.com/yoshiko-pg/difit/blob/main/package.json#L2
  - e.g. https://github.com/yoshiko-pg/difit/blob/main/package.json#L2-L5

## Affected Components
- `DiffViewer`: Main diff viewer component updated to handle multi-line comments
- `SideBySideDiffChunk`: Added logic for multi-line selection and comment creation
- `InlineComment`: Updated to work with line ranges
- `useLocalComments`: Modified hook to handle multi-line comment data
- Comment type definitions updated to support line ranges

## Benefits
- Users can now comment on blocks of code instead of individual lines
- Improves code review efficiency by allowing contextual comments across multiple lines
- Better aligns with standard code review workflows

messageHeadline: Fix git diff header parsing to handle paths without prefix (#29)
message:
Fix git diff header parsing to handle paths without prefix (#29)

The regex pattern now optionally matches the a/ and b/ prefixes in git diff headers,
allowing it to work correctly when git is configured with diff.noprefix=true.

ü§ñ Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.ai/code)

Co-authored-by: Claude <noreply@anthropic.com>

pullRequests.title: Fix git diff header parsing to handle paths without prefix
pullRequests.body:
## Problem
Currently, the git diff header parsing fails when git is configured with `diff.noprefix=true`. This configuration removes the `a/` and `b/` prefixes from file paths in diff output, causing the regex to not match and breaking the diff parsing functionality.

## Example
**With default git config (works):**
```
diff --git a/src/file.js b/src/file.js
```

**With `diff.noprefix=true` (currently broken):**
```
diff --git src/file.js src/file.js
```

## Solution
Updated the regex pattern to make the `a/` and `b/` prefixes optional using non-capturing groups `(?:[a-z]\/)?`, allowing the parser to handle both formats correctly.

## Impact
- ‚úÖ Maintains backward compatibility with default git configuration
- ‚úÖ Adds support for `diff.noprefix=true` configuration
- ‚úÖ Makes the tool more robust across different git setups
- ‚úÖ No breaking changes to existing functionality

This change ensures the tool works consistently regardless of the user's git configuration.

ü§ñ Generated with Claude Code

pullRequests.title: Add untracked file detection with CLI prompt
pullRequests.body:
## Summary
`git diff` doesn't show untracked files, which is inconvenient for this tool's purpose.
Added a check for untracked files at CLI startup.
If any are found, the user is prompted for confirmation before adding them to git's index using [`git add --intent-to-add`](https://git-scm.com/docs/git-add#Documentation/git-add.txt-code--intent-to-addcode).

## Prompt examples

User says "yes":

```
üìù Found 1 untracked file(s):
    - difftest.txt

‚ùì Would you like to include these untracked files in the diff review? (y/N): y
‚úÖ Files added with --intent-to-add
   üí° To undo this, run `git reset --mixed`
```

User says "no"(default): 

```
‚ùì Would you like to include these untracked files in the diff review? (y/N): n
‚ÑπÔ∏è Untracked files will not be shown in diff
```

pullRequests.title: feat: Add --host option to configure server bind address
pullRequests.body:
## Summary

- Added `--host` option to configure server bind address
- Enables external access to ReviewIt diff viewer when needed
- Maintains secure localhost-only default for backward compatibility

## Features

- New `--host <host>` CLI option with default value `127.0.0.1`
- Support for binding to specific IP addresses or `0.0.0.0` for external access
- Smart URL generation (displays `localhost` when host is `0.0.0.0`)
- Preserves existing port fallback logic with specified host
- Updated documentation with usage examples

## Usage

```bash
# Default behavior (localhost only)
reviewit HEAD

# Allow external access
reviewit --host 0.0.0.0 HEAD

# Bind to specific IP address
reviewit --host 192.168.1.100 HEAD

# Combine with other options
reviewit --host 0.0.0.0 --port 8080 HEAD
```

## Implementation Details

- Extended CliOptions interface to include optional host property
- Updated ServerOptions interface in server module to accept host parameter
- Modified startServerWithFallback function to use configurable host instead of hardcoded 127.0.0.1
- Enhanced URL generation logic to handle 0.0.0.0 display as localhost for better UX
- Updated README.md with CLI options table and usage examples

## Test plan

- [x] CLI help displays --host option correctly
- [x] TypeScript compilation passes with new interfaces
- [x] All existing tests continue to pass
- [x] Linting and formatting checks pass
- [x] Default behavior unchanged when --host not specified
- [x] Backward compatibility maintained

pullRequests.title: (patch) Fix port fallback behavior
pullRequests.body:
## Summary
In v1.1.7, There are bugs when the prefered port is in-use.
* Printing `localhost:undefined` as the listening server address.
* Opening browser doesn't work

#### reproduce bug
1. launch a some server on port 3000
2. run `npx reviewit`
3. The server log prints `http://localhost:undefined` in stdout
```
Port 3000 is busy, trying 3001...

üöÄ ReviewIt server started on http://localhost:undefined
üìã Reviewing: HEAD
üåê Opening browser...
```


## What I changed
Express v5 passes an Error instance to the callback function for `listen` method. https://expressjs.com/en/guide/migrating-5.html#app.listen

By using this feature, we can do error handling more easier and simple than `server.on('error', ...`.

Now, the fallback port is printed correctly and opening browser works.
```
Port 3000 is busy, trying 3001...

üöÄ ReviewIt server started on http://localhost:3001
üìã Reviewing: HEAD
üåê Opening browser...

```

message:

messageHeadline: Fix '.' argument to show HEAD vs working directory diff
message:
Fix '.' argument to show HEAD vs working directory diff

Previously, when using 'reviewit .', it incorrectly showed the diff between HEAD and its parent commit. Now it properly shows the diff between HEAD and the current working directory (including both staged and unstaged changes).

Todo completed:

messageHeadline: Auto-collapse lock files by default
message:
Auto-collapse lock files by default

Added functionality to automatically collapse common lock files when loading diffs:
- pnpm-lock.yaml, package-lock.json, yarn.lock (JavaScript/Node.js)
- Cargo.lock (Rust)
- Gemfile.lock (Ruby)
- composer.lock (PHP)
- Pipfile.lock, poetry.lock (Python)
- go.sum (Go)
- mix.lock (Elixir)

Lock files are automatically marked as 'reviewed' (collapsed) to reduce visual clutter
while still being accessible by clicking to expand when needed.
